title: Re: Porn?
content:
Wow! Pretty heavy stuff for a forum that is all about a kids gaming series where in half the episodes the bad guys either get stunned or turned into flowers!
Well, I don't think guns are evil, nor do i think people's bodies are "evil." I think its what some people do with guns (and their bodies) is evil.
I seriously don't know exactly what to thinkabout this porn thing. I think you guys could guess I don't like porn, and think I, as a Christian, should "avoid all appearance of evil," and if my eye hinders my walk with God to "pluck it out" (figuratively, people, figuratively.) I also think in a perfect world there would be no porn, but, as you all know, its not.
The problem is, I'm not sure that the government, as it is, can really justify taking away people's privacy. People deserve their privacy, and if they cross the line and invade their privacy once, they will feel more at liberty to invade it in anything and everything they do, and that's something that would be pretty bad (in the Bible, it says one of the signs of the end times would be basically something like people having to register for food, by having 666, the devil's number, written on their hand or forehead. It could be talking abot some sort of implant, technology that exists today.)
Anyway, I do think that child protection thing might be a good idea though.
Nobody's going to read this long of a post, but if you do, you just read it. (that made no sense)

title: Re: Porn?
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Wow! Pretty heavy stuff for a forum that is all about a kids gaming series where in half the episodes the bad guys either get stunned or turned into flowers![hr][/quote]

he he i guess we are all grownups but kids deep inside :]

speaking about kids, do they really suffer so much when exposed to porn? do porn really teach kids to think in a "sexism" way?
maybe it's just us grownups who are so embarassed of it so we think the kids will become psychotics if they are exposed to it?
maybe it's our traditional way of looking at the art of love in general as something forbidden and shameful.

sex (or the act of reproduce as it actually was from the begining) is just a natural thing that happens from the smallest cell to the largest animal. we are ruin our own minds by making such a basic human urge/instinct into such a taboo but still use it (sex) to attract us into consumption or to get our attention to other things (things not related to sex at all).

i say it's not healty to make such a big deal about it.
banning porn is not the answer, but alowing porn to flow freely is not the answer either. the porn concept is infact created upon this "enlarged" image we traditionally have about the subject.

so if people stoped making such a big deal about sex, porn would fall and people would be happy accepting sex as a normal part of life. but i guess that will never happen.

but as narnia4 wrote, it's an issue of privacy. how much can we let the people who rule us to sneak into out life? if we accept the first step, will we consider the next one worse?

[quote]Quote:[hr]speaking about kids, do they really suffer so much when exposed to porn?[hr][/quote]

Well it depends on what you mean by 'suffer'; porn is now the main sexual information source for children, and its not exactly factual. Studies have shown that it makes both men and women feel insecure about their bodies and more likely to seek surgery to enhance themselves. It also makes them more likely to attempt the sexual acts portrayed in order to be socially accepted. So it depends whether you think this is 'harmful' or not. [I know someone who's all too happy about the increase in anal sex]

So is killing your enemies and competitors, and death. Why don't we expose kids to death anymore I wonder?

And a large number of sexual acts portrayed in porn are very far from natural, we even manage to outdo chimps, arguably the most sexually diverse species around.

Women are trafficked for the purposes of producing pornography as well as prostitution, and even those who are not forced do not necessarily go into it of their own free will: it's either that or prostitution. This applies especially to "hardcore" pornography. (Remember that this doesn't apply to all pornography; most domestic softcore porn is produced with the actor's/protagonist's consent, but [url=http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,69006,00.html]not all[/url])

2.) Here it blends with sex as an addiction, and indeed there is indeed a semi recognised condition of sex addiction [And also nymphomania, which is mostly crap] Addiction to porn can becom a real problem, especially since there is such a large and diverse amount avalible and because its less physically limitng than sex [You can only find time to bed so many partners in a certain time, porn is more acessable, more easily and more discreetly viewed.] In severe cases a person may spend their entire waking hours in pursuit of porn. title: Re: Amen.
content:
It sucks that porn can affect some people and change them so much, but what-can-ya-do but look back on it and laugh.

Or exploit their addictions for profit, yes.

I remember back in the day, before the internet, a juvenile delinquent at my high school somehow got his thieving little hands on a big stash of porno mags (2nd hand... ew) and hid them in his locker at school, confiding only in a friend of mine.

So naturally, this friend of mine tried to steal some of these ill-gotten porno mags from the other guy's locker, by poking a ruler into it. Soon we were caught by some nasty-lookin' seniors, but once we told them what we were doing, they joined our cause and successfully removed a lot of the magazines from the locker. By now, a large crowd of teenage boys had gathered (this was an all-boys highschool!) and the pilfered magazines were being butchered among the ravenous masses, most of whom had probably never encountered a real live porno mag before and were just as much into the novelty or rarity of it as the sexual aspects.

After that day, pages of porno mag had distributed themselves all around the school, ending up in lockers, schoolbags, classrooms... And when the juvenile delinquent found out that my friend had started it all, he was not impressed. He had gone to a lot of hard work to steal those magazines from the trash at the back of a corner dairy.

So, er, back on topic, ummm, porn was fun until the internet came along and ruined it by making it easily accessible and mundane.----------
www.StrifeStrips.com! Woot! We're back, baby!

title: Re: Bad reasoning
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Our sexuality was made for re-creation; not recreation!!![hr][/quote]
And humans weren't supposed to drive cars, were they? I mean, that adrenaline rush when we go fast is supposed to tell us that we're doing something dangerous and that we should stop. We weren't supposed to wear clothes either; we were supposed to choose mates by looks rather than personality; and we weren't supposed to be able to survive with conditions that impair our survival like blindness or disability.

The human race has changed greatly in the last 10000 years. We have created all sorts of inventions: machines that calculate, eat, breathe, speak, communicate and work for us. We no longer live in small tribes, but yet still feebly attempt to apply the same behaviour model to society that we have for millennia. In short, saying that an activity is wrong because it takes advantage of our behaviour in an unnatural way is silly - I mean, that's what religion does, and there's nothing wrong with religion. (The same cannot necessarily be said of the people who use/abuse it to harm others, but that isn't relevant)

I could go on, but if I do this thread will rapidly steer off-topic - and we don't want that, do we?[url=http://last.fm/users/grafix5000/][img]http://toxicsheep.com/sigs/scrobbler.png[/img][/url]

title: Re: Bad reasoning
content:
In my opinion, 15/16 year olds should not be classified as children. They are old enough to know what porn is, and its at this age that kids get kinda interested in umm... yeah. No matter what the government does, or what parents do, "children" above 16 years of age will always find a way to get pass the barrier. I'd be more concerned about 8 year olds getting on this stuff.

as for the porn industry, well... i doubt they'll shut them all down, imagine all the law suits and the loss of revenue. and imagine all the millions of people who would complain. I think the current laws are good enough to be honest, but i think porn shouldnt be treated as such a *bad* thing. Some are into it, some arnt, tough luck.

title: Re: Bad reasoning
content:
15 and below is still a young age. I don't think that anyone younger than that should be looking at porn or ESPECIALLY be having sex.

Looking at porn at a young age can mess a person up. But then again it can mess a person up at any age... What I am saying is that below 16 is probably too young. Of course there are exceptions to this, as with anything else.

Anyway that is just my opinion on the age thing. Can you stop a determined 14 year old from looking at porn? No. I mean look at spywear. Just turn on someone's computer and before you can do anything an ad pops up with a girl fingering herself. Even if you don't want to find porn, it will still find you.

Just a little off topic but hey.-----------------------
